training_organizations.name: South Dakota DSS – CPS Training
training_organizations.description: The South Dakota Department of Social Services provides centralized training for its CPS staff (South Dakota has a state-run system). New Family Services Specialists receive training on SD’s child protection laws, forensic interviewing, safety planning, and documentation. With large Native American populations, training also covers ICWA compliance and working with tribal social services, which is critical given the state’s many ICWA cases.

training_organizations.name: Children’s Home Society of South Dakota
training_organizations.description: The oldest human services nonprofit in South Dakota, CHS operates emergency shelters, residential treatment, and foster care programs. DSS frequently partners with CHS SD, for instance by placing children in its Black Hills Children’s Home when they need temporary shelter or assessment, or by referring families to its foster/adoption program. CHS also provides statewide advocacy on child abuse prevention. Its services support the state by filling gaps for children who require care outside of a typical foster home.

training_organizations.name: Tribal Child Welfare Agencies (ICWA partners)
training_organizations.description: South Dakota’s CPS works closely with tribal child welfare programs (such as Oglala Sioux Tribe’s CPS, Standing Rock Social Services, etc.) under the Indian Child Welfare Act. While not NGOs in the traditional sense (they are tribal government agencies), they are external to the state system. These tribal agencies collaborate with DSS on investigations and placements for Native American children, sometimes taking jurisdiction of cases or identifying tribal foster homes. They ensure Native children maintain cultural connections and rights under ICWA.

policies.TribalFoster: Yes, Tribes within state provide foster care
policies.InvestQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.ScreenerQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Punishment can be considered a subtype of physical abuse or emotional maltreatment depending on action
policies.CaseManagerQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Physical neglect includes failing to provide for a child's basic needs, such as food, clothing, shelter, education, medical care or supervision, and abandonment; Neglect includes sexual penetration perpetrated by children age 10 or younger
policies.Exempt_OtherSpecify: Child's culture can be considered an exemption to emotional maltreatment
policies.NearFatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.TribalFoster_Specify: Standing Rock Sioux Tribe; Oglala Sioux Tribe; Sisseton-Wahpeton Oyate; Flandreau Santee Sioux Tribe
policies.TribalReport_Specify: Standing Rock Sioux Tribe; Oglala Sioux Tribe; Sisseton-Wahpeton Oyate; Flandreau Santee Sioux Tribe
policies.TribalScreen_Specify: Standing Rock Sioux Tribe; Oglala Sioux Tribe; Sisseton-Wahpeton Oyate; Flandreau Santee Sioux Tribe
policies.Reporter_OtherSpecify: Religious healing practitioner; Licensed or registered child welfare provider; Employee or volunteer of a child advocacy organization or child welfare service provider; Any safety-sensitive position; Any person who has reasonable cause to suspect that a child has died as a result of child abuse or neglect
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: Review of law enforcement reports; Review of physical evidence
policies.InvestStaff_OtherSpecify: Medical examiner or coroner; Division of Criminal Investigation
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: For sexual abuse, the perpetrator includes parent, guardian, custodian, and any other person responsible for the child's care; All other types of maltreatment refer to the perpetrator as parent, guardian, or custodian
policies.CentralizedReporting_Specify: Reports can be made to centralized Department of Social Services hotline or local state's attorney, Department of Social Services, or law enforcement
policies.ReporterPenalty_OtherSpecify: Religious healing practitioner; Licensed or registered child welfare provider; Employee or volunteer of a child advocacy organization or child welfare service provider; Any safety-sensitive position; Any person who has reasonable cause to suspect that a child has died as a result of child abuse or neglect
policies.AntiDiscrim_Staff_VarySpecify: (1) Race, disability, national origin, marital status, color, sex, political beliefs or affiliations are specified for staff from child welfare agency, contracted child welfare provider organizations, foster parents, kinship caregivers, and  grantees, sub-contractors, sub-grantees and business associates in connection with the performance of work required under the contracts and grants to which they are a party with the Vermont Department for Children and Families; (2) Gender identity or expression, sexual orientation, and religion are specified for staff from child welfare agency and sub-recipients of grants issued by the United States Department of Justice, Office on Violence against Women; (3) Age is specified for staff from child welfare agency and contracted child welfare provider organizations
policies.AntiDiscrim_Staff_OtherSpecify: Sub-recipients of grants issued by the United States Department of Justice, Office on Violence against Women
policies.ExtFosterCare_Criteria_OtherSpec: If youth has not yet completed the 12th grade of school or if they are in a continuing course of remedial treatment
